identity theorem

Suppose fff is a holomorphic function in the unit disk D={z∈C∣∣z∣<1}\D = \set{z \in \C \mid \abs{z} < 1}D={z∈C∣∣z∣<1}, and {xn}\set{x_n}{xn​} is a sequence of real numbers satisfying 0<xn+1<xn<10 < x_{n+1} < x_n < 10<xn+1​<xn​<1 for all n∈Nn \in \Nn∈N and lim⁡n→∞xn=0\lim_{n\to\infty} x_n = 0limn→∞​xn​=0. Show that if f(x2n+1)=f(x2n)f\p{x_{2n+1}} = f\p{x_{2n}}f(x2n+1​)=f(x2n​) for all n∈Nn \in \Nn∈N, then fff is a constant function.
Solution.

Replacing fff with f−f(0)f - f\p{0}f−f(0) if necessary, we may assume without loss of generality that f(0)=0f\p{0} = 0f(0)=0. Set g(z)=f(z)f(z‾)‾g\p{z} = f\p{z}\conj{f\p{\conj{z}}}g(z)=f(z)f(z)​. Notice that if we write f=u+ivf = u + ivf=u+iv, then f(z‾)‾=u(x,−y)−iv(x,−y)\conj{f\p{\conj{z}}} = u\p{x, -y} - iv\p{x, -y}f(z)​=u(x,−y)−iv(x,−y). Thus,

∂∂xu(x,−y)=−∂u∂x(x,−y)∂∂yu(x,−y)=−∂u∂y(x,−y)∂∂x(−v(x,−y))=−∂v∂x(x,−y)∂∂y(−v(x,−y))=−∂v∂y(x,−y).\begin{aligned} \pder{}{x} &u\p{x, -y} &= \phantom{-}\pder{u}{x}\p{x, -y} \\ \pder{}{y} &u\p{x, -y} &= -\pder{u}{y}\p{x, -y} \\ \pder{}{x} &\p{-v\p{x, -y}} &= -\pder{v}{x}\p{x, -y} \\ \pder{}{y} &\p{-v\p{x, -y}} &= \phantom{-}\pder{v}{y}\p{x, -y}. \end{aligned}∂x∂​∂y∂​∂x∂​∂y∂​​u(x,−y)u(x,−y)(−v(x,−y))(−v(x,−y))​=−∂x∂u​(x,−y)=−∂y∂u​(x,−y)=−∂x∂v​(x,−y)=−∂y∂v​(x,−y).​

Since fff is holomorphic, uuu and vvv satisfying the Cauchy-Riemann equations, and so

∂∂xu(x,−y)=∂u∂x(x,−y)=∂v∂y(x,−y)=∂∂y(−v(x,−y))∂∂yu(x,−y)=−∂u∂y(x,−y)=∂v∂x(x,−y)=−∂∂x(−v(x,−y)),\begin{gathered} \pder{}{x} u\p{x, -y} = \pder{u}{x}\p{x, -y} = \pder{v}{y}\p{x, -y} = \pder{}{y} \p{-v\p{x, -y}} \\ \pder{}{y} u\p{x, -y} = -\pder{u}{y}\p{x, -y} = \pder{v}{x}\p{x, -y} = - \pder{}{x} \p{-v\p{x, -y}}, \end{gathered}∂x∂​u(x,−y)=∂x∂u​(x,−y)=∂y∂v​(x,−y)=∂y∂​(−v(x,−y))∂y∂​u(x,−y)=−∂y∂u​(x,−y)=∂x∂v​(x,−y)=−∂x∂​(−v(x,−y)),​

so f(z‾)‾\conj{f\p{\conj{z}}}f(z)​ satisfies the Cauchy-Riemann equations, hence holomorphic, and so ggg is holomorphic.

For x∈(−1,1)x \in \p{-1, 1}x∈(−1,1), we have x‾=x\conj{x} = xx=x and so g(x)=∣f(x)∣2∈Rg\p{x} = \abs{f\p{x}}^2 \in \Rg(x)=∣f(x)∣2∈R. Hence, we may view g ⁣:(−1,1)→R\func{g}{\p{-1, 1}}{\R}g:(−1,1)→R. For n∈Nn \in \Nn∈N, we have g(x2n)=g(x2n+1)g\p{x_{2n}} = g\p{x_{2n+1}}g(x2n​)=g(x2n+1​) so by the mean value theorem, there exists yn∈(x2n+1,x2n)y_n \in \p{x_{2n+1}, x_{2n}}yn​∈(x2n+1​,x2n​) with g′(yn)=0g'\p{y_n} = 0g′(yn​)=0. Since xn→0x_n \to 0xn​→0, we have yn→0y_n \to 0yn​→0, too. In other words, the zeroes of g′g'g′ have an accumulation point at the origin, so g′g'g′ is identically 000. Thus, ggg must be constant on D\DD, since D\DD is connected. Since f(0)=0f\p{0} = 0f(0)=0, it follows that g(0)=0g\p{0} = 0g(0)=0, so ggg is identically 000.

If f(z0)≠0f\p{z_0} \neq 0f(z0​)=0 for some z0∈Dz_0 \in \Dz0​∈D, then f(z0)≠0f\p{z_0} \neq 0f(z0​)=0 on a neighborhood UUU of z0z_0z0​. Thus, since f(z)f(z‾)‾=0f\p{z}\conj{f\p{\conj{z}}} = 0f(z)f(z)​=0 on UUU, it follows that f(z‾)‾=0\conj{f\p{\conj{z}}} = 0f(z)​=0 on UUU. But this implies that f(z)f\p{z}f(z) is 000 on the open set {z‾∣z∈U}\set{\overline{z} \mid z \in U}{z∣z∈U}, so fff must be identically zero on all of D\DD, a contradiction. Thus, f(z)≡0f\p{z} \equiv 0f(z)≡0 to begin with, which completes the proof.
